title: Basic farewell phrases

titleTranslations.ja: 基本的な別れの挨拶

rule: Simple standalone phrases: Goodbye/Bye, or phrase + later: 'See you later'. Most farewells don't require additional grammar.
explanation: Fixed expressions used when parting from someone. These range from formal to casual and may indicate whether you expect to see the person again soon.

title: Basic greeting phrases

titleTranslations.ja: 基本的な挨拶表現

rule: Most greetings are standalone phrases: Hello/Hi + (person's name). Time-specific greetings follow 'Good + time period' pattern.
explanation: Simple one or two-word expressions used to acknowledge someone when meeting or parting. These are fixed phrases that don't follow typical sentence structure but are essential for polite social interaction.

title: Can I have...?

titleTranslations.ja: 〜をもらえますか？

rule: Can + I + have + [noun/item] + please?
explanation: A polite way to ask for something, especially when ordering food or drinks. This is more formal and polite than 'I want'. It's the standard way to make requests in restaurants and shows good manners.

explanations.de: Eine höfliche Art, um etwas zu bitten, besonders beim Bestellen von Essen oder Getränken. Das ist formeller und höflicher als 'Ich möchte'. Es ist die Standardart, Bitten in Restaurants zu äußern und zeigt gute Manieren.

title: Can you help me?

titleTranslations.ja: 手伝ってもらえますか？

rule: Can + you + help + me + ?
explanation: A polite way to ask someone for assistance. This question uses the modal verb 'can' to make a polite request. It's often used before asking for directions to establish that you need help.

explanations.de: Eine höfliche Art, jemanden um Hilfe zu bitten. Diese Frage verwendet das Modalverb 'können', um eine höfliche Bitte zu stellen. Es wird oft verwendet, bevor man nach dem Weg fragt, um zu signalisieren, dass man Hilfe braucht.

title: Daily Routine Integration (Review and Combination)

titleTranslations.ja: 日常生活の統合（復習と組み合わせ）

rule: Combine multiple patterns: [Family member] + [has/have] + [daily activity] + [time/location]. Use possessive adjectives consistently and connect activities with sequence words.
explanation: This lesson integrates all grammar patterns learned in the unit to describe family members' daily activities. Students practice combining possessive adjectives (my, his, her), have/has, present tense verbs, and location expressions to create coherent descriptions of family life.

explanations.ja: この課は、家族の日常活動を説明するために、このユニットで学んだ全ての文法パターンを統合します。学生は所有形容詞（my、his、her）、have/has、現在形動詞、場所表現を組み合わせて、家族生活の一貫した説明を作る練習をします。
explanations.de: Diese Lektion integriert alle in der Einheit erlernten Grammatikmuster, um die täglichen Aktivitäten von Familienmitgliedern zu beschreiben. Die Schüler üben die Kombination von besitzanzeigenden Adjektiven (mein, sein, ihr), haben/hat, Präsensverben und Ortsangaben, um kohärente Beschreibungen des Familienlebens zu erstellen.

title: Dialogue Review: All Unit Grammar

titleTranslations.ja: 対話復習：ユニット全体の文法

rule: Combines multiple patterns: Can I have + noun? / I'd like + noun / How much is + singular noun? / How much are + plural noun? / some + noun (positive) / any + noun (questions/negatives)
explanation: Comprehensive review and integration of all grammar patterns learned in this unit: making requests (What do you want?, Can I have...?, I'd like...), asking about quantities (How much/How many?), asking about prices (How much is...?/How much are...?), and using some/any appropriately in shopping and restaurant contexts.

explanations.ja: このユニットで学んだ全ての文法パターンの包括的な復習と統合：依頼の仕方（What do you want?、Can I have...?、I'd like...）、量の尋ね方（How much/How many?）、値段の尋ね方（How much is...?/How much are...?）、ショッピングやレストランでの適切なsome/anyの使い方。
explanations.de: Umfassende Wiederholung und Integration aller in dieser Einheit erlernten Grammatikmuster: Bitten stellen (Was möchten Sie?, Kann ich... haben?, Ich hätte gern...), nach Mengen fragen (Wie viel/Wie viele?), nach Preisen fragen (Wie viel kostet...?/Wie viel kosten...?), und angemessene Verwendung von einige/etwas in Einkaufs- und Restaurantkontexten.

title: Excuse me, where is...?

titleTranslations.ja: すみません、〜はどこですか？

rule: Excuse me, where is + place/location + ?
explanation: A polite way to ask for the location of a place. 'Excuse me' gets attention politely, and 'where is' asks for location. This is the standard, respectful way to ask strangers for directions.

explanations.ja: 場所を尋ねる丁寧な方法です。「すみません」で丁寧に注意を引き、「どこですか」で場所を尋ねます。これは見知らぬ人に道を尋ねる標準的で敬意ある方法です。
explanations.de: Eine höfliche Art, nach dem Standort eines Ortes zu fragen. 'Entschuldigung' erregt höflich Aufmerksamkeit, und 'wo ist' fragt nach dem Ort. Das ist die standardmäßige, respektvolle Art, Fremde nach dem Weg zu fragen.

title: Go by + transport

titleTranslations.ja: 〜で行く（交通手段）

rule: Subject + go/goes + by + transport noun (without 'the' for most transport types)
explanation: This pattern is used to describe the method of transportation you use to travel somewhere. 'Go by' is followed by the type of transport (bus, car, train, etc.). It answers the question 'How do you get there?' This is the most common way to talk about transportation methods in English.

explanations.ja: どこかへ行く時に使う交通手段を説明するパターンです。「Go by」の後に交通手段の種類（バス、車、電車など）が続きます。「どうやってそこに行きますか？」という質問に答えます。これは英語で交通手段について話す最も一般的な方法です。
explanations.de: Dieses Muster wird verwendet, um die Transportmethode zu beschreiben, die Sie verwenden, um irgendwohin zu reisen. 'Fahren mit' wird gefolgt von der Art des Transports (Bus, Auto, Zug, etc.). Es beantwortet die Frage 'Wie kommen Sie dorthin?' Das ist die gebräuchlichste Art, über Transportmethoden im Englischen zu sprechen.

title: I + base verb (present simple - first person)

titleTranslations.ja: 私＋動詞の原形（現在形・一人称）
titleTranslations.de: Ich + Grundform des Verbs (Präsens - erste Person)

rule: Subject (I) + base verb + (object/complement). Examples: I wake up, I brush my teeth, I eat breakfast. For negative: I do not (don't) + base verb. For questions: Do I + base verb?
explanation: Used to describe habitual actions, daily routines, and general facts about yourself. The present simple with 'I' uses the base form of the verb (infinitive without 'to'). This is essential for talking about what you do regularly, including daily morning activities.

explanations.ja: 習慣的な行動、日課、自分についての一般的な事実を説明するのに使います。「I」を使う現在形では動詞の原形（toのない不定詞）を使います。これは自分が定期的にすることについて話すのに欠かせません。朝の日課の活動も含みます。
explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um gewohnheitsmäßige Handlungen, tägliche Routinen und allgemeine Fakten über sich selbst zu beschreiben. Das Präsens mit 'Ich' verwendet die Grundform des Verbs (Infinitiv ohne 'zu'). Das ist unerlässlich, um darüber zu sprechen, was Sie regelmäßig tun, einschließlich täglicher Morgenaktivitäten.

title: Prepositions of place: in, on, under, next to

titleTranslations.ja: 場所の前置詞：in, on, under, next to
titleTranslations.de: Ortsangaben: in, on, under, next to

rule: Subject + be + preposition + noun (The book is on the table) OR There + is/are + noun + preposition + noun (There is a book on the table)
explanation: Prepositions that show the position or location of objects in relation to other objects. 'In' shows something is inside an enclosed space, 'on' shows something is touching a surface from above, 'under' shows something is below another object, and 'next to' shows things are beside each other. These work with 'there is/there are' to describe locations.

explanations.ja: 他の物との関係で物の位置や場所を示す前置詞です。'In'は何かが囲まれた空間の中にあることを示し、'on'は何かが上から表面に触れていることを示し、'under'は何かが他の物の下にあることを示し、'next to'は物同士が隣り合っていることを示します。これらは'there is/there are'と一緒に使って場所を説明します。
explanations.de: Präpositionen, die die Position oder Lage von Objekten im Verhältnis zu anderen Objekten zeigen. 'In' zeigt, dass sich etwas in einem geschlossenen Raum befindet, 'on' zeigt, dass etwas eine Oberfläche von oben berührt, 'under' zeigt, dass sich etwas unter einem anderen Objekt befindet, und 'next to' zeigt, dass Dinge nebeneinander stehen. Diese funktionieren mit 'there is/there are', um Orte zu beschreiben.

title: frequency adverbs (always, usually, sometimes, never, often)

titleTranslations.ja: 頻度の副詞（always, usually, sometimes, never, often）

rule: Subject + frequency adverb + main verb OR Subject + be + frequency adverb + adjective/noun. Most frequency adverbs go BEFORE the main verb but AFTER the 'be' verb. 'Sometimes' can also go at the beginning or end of sentences.
explanation: Frequency adverbs tell us how often something happens. They express the regularity of actions and habits in daily life. Always (100%) > usually (80-90%) > often (60-70%) > sometimes (30-50%) > never (0%). These words help make our descriptions of routines more precise and natural.

Always (100%) > usually (80-90%) > often (60-70%) > sometimes (30-50%) > never (0%). Diese Wörter helfen dabei, unsere Beschreibungen von Routinen präziser und natürlicher zu machen.

rule: Possessive adjective + noun. Always comes directly before the noun it modifies. Cannot be used alone - must be followed by a noun. Order: [possessive adjective] + [noun]
explanation: Possessive adjectives show ownership or relationship between people and things. They come before nouns to indicate who something belongs to or who someone is related to. title: present simple - he/she/it + verb + s

titleTranslations.ja: 現在形 - he/she/it + 動詞 + s

rule: Subject (he/she/it/name) + verb + s + rest of sentence. For most verbs, add -s: work→works, eat→eats. For verbs ending in -ch, -sh, -s, -x, -z, add -es: watch→watches
explanation: Used to describe habits, facts, and regular actions for third person singular (he, she, it). The verb takes an -s ending. This pattern extends the present simple you learned for 'I' and 'you' to include other people and things.

rule: Subject + don't/doesn't + base verb. Don't = do not, doesn't = does not. The main verb always stays in base form (no -s ending even for he/she/it).
explanation: Used to express what someone does NOT do regularly, habitually, or as a general fact. Shows absence of regular actions or states. 'Don't' is used with I/you/we/they, and 'doesn't' is used with he/she/it.

title: some/any

titleTranslations.ja: some/any

rule: some/any + noun (countable plural or uncountable). Positive: some + noun. Negative: not + any + noun. Questions: any + noun (in most cases)
explanation: Some and any are used to talk about indefinite quantities. 'Some' is used in positive statements and offers ('I have some apples', 'Would you like some coffee?'). 'Any' is used in negative statements and questions ('I don't have any money', 'Do you have any questions?'). Both can be used with countable and uncountable nouns, but the choice depends on the type of sentence.

explanations.ja: SomeとAnyは不定の量について話すときに使われます。'Some'は肯定文と申し出で使われます（'I have some apples', 'Would you like some coffee?'）。'Any'は否定文と疑問文で使われます（'I don't have any money', 'Do you have any questions?'）。どちらも可算名詞と不可算名詞の両方で使えますが、選択は文の種類によります。
explanations.de: Some und any werden verwendet, um über unbestimmte Mengen zu sprechen. 'Some' wird in positiven Aussagen und Angeboten verwendet ('Ich habe einige Äpfel', 'Möchtest du etwas Kaffee?'). 'Any' wird in negativen Aussagen und Fragen verwendet ('Ich habe kein Geld', 'Hast du Fragen?'). Beide können mit zählbaren und unzählbaren Substantiven verwendet werden, aber die Wahl hängt von der Art des Satzes ab.

title: there is/there are

titleTranslations.ja: there is/there are

rule: There is + singular noun + location. There are + plural noun + location. Examples: There is a table in the kitchen. There are two chairs in the room.
explanation: Used to say that something exists or is present in a place. 'There is' for singular nouns, 'there are' for plural nouns. This is different from describing what you own (have/has) - it describes what exists in a location.

explanation.de: Dieses Muster verwendet das Verb 'be' (am, is, are, was, were) gefolgt von einem Adjektiv, um jemandes Persönlichkeit oder Charakterzüge zu beschreiben. Dies ist die häufigste Art, zu beschreiben, wie jemand als Person ist. Das Adjektiv kommt direkt nach der Form von 'be' ohne andere Wörter dazwischen.

title: be going to + infinitive

titleTranslations.ja: be going to + 不定詞

rule: Subject + am/is/are + going to + base form of verb. Examples: I am going to visit my family. She is going to watch a movie. We are going to have a party.
explanation: Used to express future plans, intentions, and predictions based on present evidence. This structure shows that you have already decided to do something in the future. It's more personal and immediate than 'will' and emphasizes that the plan was made before the moment of speaking.

explanations.ja: 将来の計画、意図、現在の証拠に基づく予測を表現するために使われます。この構造は将来何かをすることを既に決めていることを示します。'will'よりも個人的で直接的で、話している瞬間より前に計画が立てられたことを強調します。
explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um zukünftige Pläne, Absichten und Vorhersagen basierend auf gegenwärtigen Beweisen auszudrücken. Diese Struktur zeigt, dass Sie bereits entschieden haben, etwas in der Zukunft zu tun. Es ist persönlicher und unmittelbarer als 'will' und betont, dass der Plan vor dem Sprechmoment gemacht wurde.

examples.english: I am going to visit my family this weekend.
She is going to watch a movie tonight.
We don't usually have parties, but we are going to have one next week.
Are you going to be excited about the party tomorrow?
My family is going to visit different places next weekend.
How often do you make plans? I am going to plan more activities.

title: comparative adjectives with -er

titleTranslations.ja: -erを使った比較形容詞

rule: For 1-syllable adjectives: adjective + -er + than (tall → taller than). For 2-syllable adjectives ending in -y: change y to i + -er + than (funny → funnier than). For adjectives ending in consonant-vowel-consonant: double final consonant + -er (big → bigger).
explanation: Used to compare two people or things when one has more of a quality than the other. For short adjectives (1 syllable, or 2 syllables ending in -y), add -er to the adjective and use 'than' to introduce the comparison.

explanations.ja: 一方が他方よりもある性質を多く持っている場合に、2人または2つの物を比較するために使われます。短い形容詞（1音節、または-yで終わる2音節）の場合、形容詞に-erを付けて、'than'を使って比較の対象を導入します。
explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um zwei Personen oder Dinge zu vergleichen, wenn eine mehr von einer Eigenschaft hat als die andere. Für kurze Adjektive (1 Silbe oder 2 Silben, die auf -y enden), füge -er zum Adjektiv hinzu und verwende 'than', um den Vergleich einzuführen.

The train is faster than the car in the city.

Can I have the smaller phone, please?

title: future time expressions

titleTranslations.ja: 未来時間表現

rule: Time expressions can come at the beginning or end of sentences: 'In 10 years, people will live on Mars' or 'People will live on Mars in 10 years'. Common expressions: next + time (next year), in + number + time (in 5 years), by + time (by 2030), soon, later, someday, eventually.
explanation: Words and phrases that tell us when something will happen in the future. These include specific times (next week, in 2030) and general times (soon, later, someday). They help make predictions and plans clearer by showing exactly when we expect something to happen.

explanations.ja: 将来何かが起こる時を教えてくれる単語や句です。これには特定の時間（next week, in 2030）と一般的な時間（soon, later, someday）が含まれます。いつ何かが起こることを期待しているかを正確に示すことで、予測や計画をより明確にするのに役立ちます。
explanations.de: Wörter und Phrasen, die uns sagen, wann etwas in der Zukunft geschehen wird. Dazu gehören spezifische Zeiten (nächste Woche, im Jahr 2030) und allgemeine Zeiten (bald, später, eines Tages). Sie helfen, Vorhersagen und Pläne klarer zu machen, indem sie genau zeigen, wann wir erwarten, dass etwas passiert.

examples.english: In 10 years, technology will probably change how we eat breakfast.
I'm going to start a career in artificial intelligence next year.
People will definitely work from remote locations in the future.
By 2030, our lifestyle will be very different because of the environment.
I'm excited because I'm going to watch a movie about technology someday.
The weather will probably be different in 5 years due to environmental changes.
Look at this receipt - technology is going to make shopping easier soon.

explanation: This structure is used to indicate possession of body parts or to describe physical problems. 'Have' shows that something belongs to or affects your body. Unlike temporary states, this shows what your body contains or experiences.

explanations.de: Diese Struktur wird verwendet, um den Besitz von Körperteilen anzuzeigen oder körperliche Probleme zu beschreiben. 'Have' zeigt, dass etwas zu Ihrem Körper gehört oder ihn betrifft. Im Gegensatz zu vorübergehenden Zuständen zeigt dies, was Ihr Körper enthält oder erlebt.

title: have to + base verb

rule: Subject + have/has to + base form of verb. Question: Do/Does + subject + have to + base verb? Negative: don't/doesn't have to (means not necessary, no obligation)

explanations.ja: 通常、外的状況、規則、実用的要件に基づく必要性や義務を表現します。'must'より格式張らず、話し言葉でより一般的です。外的要因により何かが必要であることを示します。
explanations.de: Drückt Notwendigkeit oder Verpflichtung aus, meist basierend auf äußeren Umständen, Regeln oder praktischen Anforderungen. Weniger förmlich als 'must' und häufiger in der gesprochenen Sprache. Zeigt, dass etwas aufgrund äußerer Faktoren notwendig ist.

explanation: Irregular verbs have unique past tense forms that don't follow the regular -ed pattern. These forms must be memorized as they don't follow predictable rules. Common irregular verbs include go→went, see→saw, have→had, eat→ate, buy→bought, come→came.

title: past simple - regular verbs

titleTranslations.ja: 過去形 - 規則動詞

rule: Subject + verb + -ed (for regular verbs). Examples: I walked, You cooked, She played, We visited. For verbs ending in -e, just add -d (liked). For verbs ending in consonant + y, change y to i and add -ed (studied).
explanation: The past simple tense describes completed actions that happened at a specific time in the past. Regular verbs form the past tense by adding -ed to the base form. This is the most basic way to talk about past events and is essential for storytelling and describing experiences.

explanations.ja: 過去形は過去の特定の時間に起こった完了した行動を表します。規則動詞は動詞の原形に-edを付けることで過去形を作ります。これは過去の出来事について話すための最も基本的な方法で、物語を語ったり経験を説明したりするのに不可欠です。

Regelmäßige Verben bilden die Vergangenheitsform durch Hinzufügen von -ed zur Grundform. Dies ist die grundlegendste Art, über vergangene Ereignisse zu sprechen und ist wesentlich für das Erzählen und Beschreiben von Erfahrungen.

title: present continuous for future arrangements

titleTranslations.ja: 将来の約束のための現在進行形

rule: Subject + am/is/are + verb-ing + time expression. Examples: 'I am meeting John tomorrow', 'We are having dinner at 7pm', 'She is visiting her family next weekend'
explanation: We use the present continuous (am/is/are + verb-ing) to talk about planned future activities that are already arranged or scheduled. This is different from 'going to' which expresses intentions. Present continuous for future shows that the arrangement is definite and often involves other people.

explanations.ja: すでに取り決められたり予定されたりしている将来の計画的活動について話すために現在進行形（am/is/are + 動詞-ing）を使用します。これは意図を表現する'going to'とは異なります。将来の現在進行形は取り決めが確定しており、しばしば他の人々を巻き込むことを示します。
explanations.de: Wir verwenden das Present Continuous (am/is/are + Verb-ing), um über geplante zukünftige Aktivitäten zu sprechen, die bereits vereinbart oder geplant sind. Dies unterscheidet sich von 'going to', das Absichten ausdrückt. Present Continuous für die Zukunft zeigt, dass die Vereinbarung definitiv ist und oft andere Personen einbezieht.

title: present perfect vs past simple

titleTranslations.ja: 現在完了形対過去形

rule: Present perfect: have/has + past participle (I have visited Paris). Past simple: verb + ed or irregular form + time expression (I visited Paris last year)
explanation: Two different ways to talk about past experiences. Present perfect (have/has + past participle) focuses on the experience itself and connects to the present moment - it doesn't specify when something happened. Past simple focuses on a specific completed action at a definite time in the past. Use present perfect for general life experiences and past simple for specific events with time details.

explanations.ja: 過去の経験について話す二つの異なる方法です。現在完了形（have/has + 過去分詞）は経験自体に焦点を当て、現在の瞬間とつながっています - いつ何かが起こったかは特定しません。過去形は過去の明確な時間での特定の完了した行動に焦点を当てます。一般的な人生経験には現在完了形を、時間詳細のある特定の出来事には過去形を使用します。
explanations.de: Zwei verschiedene Arten, über vergangene Erfahrungen zu sprechen. Present Perfect (have/has + Partizip Perfekt) konzentriert sich auf die Erfahrung selbst und verbindet sich mit dem gegenwärtigen Moment - es gibt nicht an, wann etwas passiert ist. Past Simple konzentriert sich auf eine bestimmte abgeschlossene Handlung zu einer bestimmten Zeit in der Vergangenheit. Verwende Present Perfect für allgemeine Lebenserfahrungen und Past Simple für spezifische Ereignisse mit Zeitangaben.

title: present perfect with ever/never

titleTranslations.ja: ever/neverを使った現在完了形

rule: have/has + past participle. Questions: Have/Has + subject + ever + past participle? Negative: Subject + have/has + never + past participle. Note: Don't use 'not' with 'never' - it's already negative.
explanation: The present perfect tense is used to talk about life experiences up to now, without specifying exactly when they happened. 'Ever' is used in questions to ask about any time in someone's life. 'Never' is used in negative statements to say something has not happened at any time. This tense connects past experiences to the present moment and is essential for talking about what you have or haven't done in your life.

explanations.ja: 現在完了時制は、正確にいつ起こったかを特定せずに、今までの人生経験について話すのに使用されます。'Ever'は誰かの人生のどの時点についても尋ねる質問で使用されます。'Never'は何かがいかなる時にも起こっていないことを言う否定文で使用されます。この時制は過去の経験を現在の瞬間と結び付け、人生で何をしたことがあるか、ないかについて話すのに不可欠です。
explanations.de: Das Present Perfect wird verwendet, um über Lebenserfahrungen bis jetzt zu sprechen, ohne genau anzugeben, wann sie passiert sind. 'Ever' wird in Fragen verwendet, um nach irgendeiner Zeit im Leben einer Person zu fragen. 'Never' wird in verneinten Aussagen verwendet, um zu sagen, dass etwas zu keiner Zeit passiert ist. Diese Zeitform verbindet vergangene Erfahrungen mit dem gegenwärtigen Moment und ist wesentlich, um darüber zu sprechen, was man im Leben getan oder nicht getan hat.

I have never tried expensive sushi, but I should visit Japan someday.
Has she ever flown in an airplane? Flying costs a lot, but it's comfortable.
We have never climbed a mountain because we're nervous about it.

title: present simple vs present continuous

titleTranslations.ja: 現在形対現在進行形

rule: Present simple: Subject + base verb (+ s for he/she/it). Present continuous: Subject + am/is/are + verb + -ing. Use present simple for schedules, habits, and facts. Use present continuous for actions in progress, temporary situations, and current activities.
explanation: Present simple describes regular habits, routines, and permanent situations (I work at 9 AM every day). Present continuous describes actions happening right now or temporary situations (I am working on a project this week). This distinction is crucial for describing workplace routines versus current activities.

explanations.ja: 現在形は規則的な習慣、ルーチン、恒久的な状況を表します（毎日午前9時に仕事をします）。現在進行形は今まさに起こっている行動や一時的な状況を表します（今週プロジェクトに取り組んでいます）。この区別は職場のルーチンと現在の活動を表現するのに重要です。
explanations.de: Present Simple beschreibt regelmäßige Gewohnheiten, Routinen und dauerhafte Situationen (Ich arbeite jeden Tag um 9 Uhr). Present Continuous beschreibt Handlungen, die gerade jetzt passieren, oder temporäre Situationen (Ich arbeite diese Woche an einem Projekt). Diese Unterscheidung ist entscheidend für die Beschreibung von Arbeitsroutinen versus aktuellen Aktivitäten.

rule: Subject + am/is/are + a/an + job OR Subject + work/works + as + a/an + job. Remember to add 's' to verbs with he/she/it.
explanation: Use the present simple tense to describe someone's job or profession. This pattern tells us what work someone does regularly. 'Works as a' emphasizes the role or function, while 'is a' simply states the profession.

title: review: present perfect

titleTranslations.ja: 復習：現在完了形

rule: have/has + past participle (I have visited, She has been, We have seen)
explanation: The present perfect tense connects past actions or experiences to the present. It's used to talk about travel experiences without specifying when exactly they happened, or to describe recent travel-related actions that affect current planning decisions.

explanations.ja: 現在完了時制は過去の行動や経験を現在に結び付けます。正確にいつ起こったかを特定せずに旅行経験について話したり、現在の計画決定に影響する最近の旅行関連行動を表現したりするのに使用されます。
explanations.de: Das Present Perfect verbindet vergangene Handlungen oder Erfahrungen mit der Gegenwart. Es wird verwendet, um über Reiseerfahrungen zu sprechen, ohne genau anzugeben, wann sie stattfanden, oder um kürzliche reisebezogene Handlungen zu beschreiben, die aktuelle Planungsentscheidungen beeinflussen.

title: review: should, must, have to

titleTranslations.ja: 復習：should、must、have to

rule: should + base verb, must + base verb, have to + base verb. Negative: shouldn't, must not/mustn't, don't have to
explanation: This lesson reviews three ways to give advice and talk about obligations. 'Should' gives advice or recommendations ('You should exercise'). 'Must' shows strong obligation or rules ('You must not smoke in school'). 'Have to' shows necessity or external obligation ('I have to work late'). These patterns are essential for discussing lifestyle choices and health advice.

explanations.ja: このレッスンでは、アドバイスや義務について話す3つの方法を復習します。'Should'はアドバイスや推奨を与える（'運動すべきです'）。'Must'は強い義務や規則を示す（'学校では喫煙してはいけません'）。'Have to'は必要性や外的義務を示す（'遅くまで働かなければなりません'）。これらのパターンは、ライフスタイルの選択や健康のアドバイスについて議論するのに不可欠です。
explanations.de: Diese Lektion wiederholt drei Arten, Ratschläge zu geben und über Verpflichtungen zu sprechen. 'Should' gibt Ratschläge oder Empfehlungen ('Du solltest Sport treiben'). 'Must' zeigt starke Verpflichtung oder Regeln ('Du darfst in der Schule nicht rauchen'). 'Have to' zeigt Notwendigkeit oder externe Verpflichtung ('Ich muss lange arbeiten'). Diese Strukturen sind wichtig für Diskussionen über Lebensstil und Gesundheitsratschläge.

title: reviewing all future forms in context

titleTranslations.ja: 文脈における全ての未来形の復習

rule:
1. Will + base verb: 'I will pack tonight' (prediction/spontaneous decision)
2. Be going to + base verb: 'We are going to visit Paris' (plan/intention)
3. Present continuous: 'We are flying tomorrow at 3 PM' (fixed arrangement)
explanation: This lesson integrates the three main future forms in English: 'will' for predictions and spontaneous decisions, 'be going to' for plans and intentions, and present continuous for fixed arrangements. Understanding when to use each form is crucial for natural communication about future events, especially when discussing travel plans which involve all three types of future reference.

explanations.ja: このレッスンでは、英語の3つの主要な未来形を統合します：予測と自発的決定の'will'、計画と意図の'be going to'、確定した約束の現在進行形。いつ各形式を使用するかを理解することは、未来の出来事について自然にコミュニケーションを取るために重要で、特に3つのタイプの未来参照をすべて含む旅行計画について話すときに重要です。
explanations.de: Diese Lektion integriert die drei wichtigsten Zukunftsformen im Englischen: 'will' für Vorhersagen und spontane Entscheidungen, 'be going to' für Pläne und Absichten, und Present Continuous für feste Vereinbarungen. Das Verständnis, wann jede Form zu verwenden ist, ist entscheidend für natürliche Kommunikation über zukünftige Ereignisse, besonders bei Reiseplänen, die alle drei Arten der Zukunftsbezugnahme beinhalten.

title: sequence words

titleTranslations.ja: 順序を表す語

rule: Sequence word + clause. Often at the beginning of sentences: 'First, I...' 'Then, we...' 'After graduation, she...'
explanation: Words and phrases that show the order of events in stories: first, then, after, next, finally, later. These help organize life stories and make them easier to follow.

explanations.ja: 物語の出来事の順序を示す語句：まず、それから、その後、次に、最後に、後で。これらは人生の物語を整理し、理解しやすくするのに役立ちます。
explanations.de: Wörter und Phrasen, die die Reihenfolge der Ereignisse in Geschichten zeigen: zuerst, dann, nach, als nächstes, schließlich, später. Diese helfen dabei, Lebensgeschichten zu organisieren und sie leichter nachvollziehbar zu machen.

We usually ate dinner together and then watched TV as a family.
Finally, I was disappointed because the job was very different from what I expected.

title: should/shouldn't + base verb

titleTranslations.ja: should/shouldn't + 動詞の原形

rule: Subject + should/shouldn't + base form of verb (no -s, -ed, -ing). Questions: Should + subject + base verb? Negatives: Subject + shouldn't + base verb.
explanation: Modal verb used to give advice, make recommendations, or express what is right or wrong to do. 'Should' indicates something is advisable or recommended, while 'shouldn't' indicates something is not advisable.

explanations.ja: アドバイスを与えたり、推奨したり、何が正しいか間違いかを表現するために使用される法助動詞。'Should'は何かが推奨される、または勧められることを示し、'shouldn't'は何かが推奨されないことを示します。
explanations.de: Modalverb, das verwendet wird, um Ratschläge zu geben, Empfehlungen auszusprechen oder auszudrücken, was richtig oder falsch zu tun ist. 'Should' zeigt an, dass etwas ratsam oder empfehlenswert ist, während 'shouldn't' anzeigt, dass etwas nicht ratsam ist.

You shouldn't watch expensive movies when you have a headache.
She should drink water and see a doctor.
You should exercise, but you shouldn't exercise when you feel sick.
Yesterday I watched TV, but I should have slept early.
You should eat healthy food - it's not expensive.

title: will + infinitive for predictions

titleTranslations.ja: 予測のwill + 不定詞

rule: Subject + will + base verb (infinitive without 'to'). Negative: Subject + will not (won't) + base verb. Question: Will + subject + base verb?
explanation: Used to make predictions about the future based on what you think will happen. 'Will' expresses certainty or strong belief about future events, especially for weather, general facts, or spontaneous decisions. More certain than 'going to' for predictions.

explanations.ja: 何が起こると思うかに基づいて未来について予測をするために使用されます。'Will'は未来の出来事、特に天気、一般的な事実、または自発的な決定について確信や強い信念を表現します。予測において'going to'よりも確実です。
explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um Vorhersagen über die Zukunft basierend auf dem zu machen, was man denkt, dass passieren wird. 'Will' drückt Gewissheit oder starken Glauben über zukünftige Ereignisse aus, besonders für Wetter, allgemeine Fakten oder spontane Entscheidungen. Sicherer als 'going to' für Vorhersagen.

title: will vs going to comparison

titleTranslations.ja: will vs going toの比較

rule: 'Will' + base verb (will work, will change). 'Going to' + base verb (am/is/are going to work, going to change). Both can be used with future time expressions.
explanation: Both 'will' and 'going to' talk about the future, but they have different uses. 'Will' is for predictions based on what we think might happen, spontaneous decisions, and promises. 'Going to' is for plans we've already decided and predictions based on present evidence we can see now.

explanations.ja: 'Will'と'going to'は両方とも未来について話しますが、異なる用法があります。'Will'は起こるかもしれないと思うことに基づく予測、自発的決定、約束のためです。'Going to'は既に決めた計画や、現在見ることができる証拠に基づく予測のためです。
explanations.de: Sowohl 'will' als auch 'going to' sprechen über die Zukunft, aber sie haben verschiedene Verwendungen. 'Will' ist für Vorhersagen basierend auf dem, was wir denken, dass passieren könnte, spontane Entscheidungen und Versprechen. 'Going to' ist für Pläne, die wir bereits entschieden haben, und Vorhersagen basierend auf gegenwärtigen Beweisen, die wir jetzt sehen können.

explanation: These phrases introduce personal opinions with varying degrees of certainty. 'Think' is most common and neutral, 'believe' suggests stronger conviction, and 'feel' emphasizes emotional or intuitive responses rather than logical reasoning.

explanations.de: Diese Phrasen leiten persönliche Meinungen mit verschiedenen Graden der Gewissheit ein. 'Think' ist am häufigsten und neutral, 'believe' deutet auf stärkere Überzeugung hin, und 'feel' betont emotionale oder intuitive Reaktionen statt logische Begründung.

title: Mixed conditionals (third + second conditional)

titleTranslations.ja: 混合条件法（第3条件法 + 第2条件法）

rule: If + past perfect, would + base verb (present result of past condition). Example: If I had studied harder (past), I would be a doctor now (present result).
explanation: Mixed conditionals combine different time periods to show how past actions affect present situations or how present situations would have affected past events. The third + second mixed conditional shows how a past action (or lack of action) affects the present situation.

explanations.ja: 混合条件法は、過去の行動が現在の状況にどのように影響するか、または現在の状況が過去の出来事にどのように影響したであろうかを示すために、異なる時間帯を組み合わせます。第3 + 第2混合条件法は、過去の行動（または行動の欠如）が現在の状況にどのように影響するかを示します。
explanations.de: Gemischte Konditionalsätze kombinieren verschiedene Zeitperioden, um zu zeigen, wie vergangene Handlungen gegenwärtige Situationen beeinflussen oder wie gegenwärtige Situationen vergangene Ereignisse beeinflusst hätten. Der dritte + zweite gemischte Konditional zeigt, wie eine vergangene Handlung (oder das Fehlen einer Handlung) die gegenwärtige Situation beeinflusst.

examples.english: If I had taken that job opportunity five years ago, I would be living in a different city now.
She regrets her decision because if she had studied medicine, she would have a completely different career today.
If we hadn't made that costly mistake in our business plan, we would be grateful for our current situation.
I can imagine the consequences if I had chosen a different path when I was young - I would probably have different opportunities now.
If he had been more careful with his financial decisions last year, his current situation would be much better.

title: Narrative tense integration with reflective language

titleTranslations.ja: 反省的言語との物語時制統合
titleTranslations.de: Integration narrativer Zeiten mit reflektierender Sprache

rule: Past tenses for events + reflective phrases (Looking back, I realize that... / This experience taught me that... / Now I understand that...) + present tenses for current understanding
explanation: Combining all narrative tenses (past simple, past continuous, past perfect) with reflective phrases to tell complete stories that include both events and their significance. This integrates storytelling with personal reflection and meaning-making.

explanations.ja: すべての物語時制（過去形、過去進行形、過去完了形）を反省的なフレーズと組み合わせて、出来事とその意義の両方を含む完全な物語を語ること。これは物語と個人的な反省と意味づくりを統合します。
explanations.de: Die Kombination aller narrativen Zeiten (Past Simple, Past Continuous, Past Perfect) mit reflektierenden Phrasen, um vollständige Geschichten zu erzählen, die sowohl Ereignisse als auch ihre Bedeutung beinhalten. Dies integriert Geschichtenerzählen mit persönlicher Reflexion und Sinngebung.

title: Narrative tense review (past simple, past continuous, past perfect)

titleTranslations.ja: 物語時制の復習（過去形、過去進行形、過去完了形）
titleTranslations.de: Wiederholung narrativer Zeiten (Past Simple, Past Continuous, Past Perfect)

rule: Past simple: subject + past verb. Past continuous: was/were + -ing. Past perfect: had + past participle. Use time words like 'while', 'when', 'before', 'after' to connect events.
explanation: When telling stories, we combine different past tenses to show the sequence and relationship between events. Past simple for main events, past continuous for background/ongoing actions, and past perfect for events that happened before the main story time.

explanations.ja: 物語を語るとき、出来事の順序と関係を示すために異なる過去時制を組み合わせます。主要な出来事には過去形、背景/継続的な行動には過去進行形、主要な物語時間より前に起こった出来事には過去完了形を使用します。
explanations.de: Beim Geschichtenerzählen kombinieren wir verschiedene Vergangenheitszeiten, um die Reihenfolge und Beziehung zwischen Ereignissen zu zeigen. Past Simple für Hauptereignisse, Past Continuous für Hintergrund/andauernde Handlungen, und Past Perfect für Ereignisse, die vor der Hauptgeschichtszeit passiert sind.

title: Tense backshift in reported speech

titleTranslations.ja: 間接話法における時制の後退

rule: Direct speech tense → Reported speech tense: Present simple → Past simple (say/says → said), Present continuous → Past continuous (am/is/are + -ing → was/were + -ing), Past simple → Past perfect (did/went → had done/had gone), Present perfect → Past perfect (have/has done → had done), will → would, can → could, may → might
explanation: When reporting what someone said in the past, verb tenses usually move one step back into the past. This is called backshift. Present simple becomes past simple, present continuous becomes past continuous, past simple becomes past perfect, etc.

explanations.ja: 過去に誰かが言ったことを報告するとき、動詞の時制は通常過去に一歩戻ります。これは時制の後退と呼ばれます。現在形は過去形になり、現在進行形は過去進行形になり、過去形は過去完了形になります。

title: Time expression changes in reported speech

titleTranslations.ja: 間接話法における時間表現の変化

rule: now → then, today → that day, yesterday → the day before, tomorrow → the next day/the following day, this week → that week, last week → the week before/the previous week, next week → the following week, ago → before, recently → had recently
explanation: When reporting speech, time expressions must change to reflect the new time perspective. Words like 'now', 'today', 'yesterday' change to 'then', 'that day', 'the day before' because the speaker is reporting from a different time point.

explanations.ja: 話法を報告する際、時間表現は新しい時間的視点を反映するように変化させる必要があります。「今」、「今日」、「昨日」などの語は、話し手が異なる時点から報告しているため「その時」、「その日」、「前日」に変わります。
explanations.de: Bei der Wiedergabe von Rede müssen Zeitausdrücke geändert werden, um die neue Zeitperspektive zu reflektieren. Wörter wie 'jetzt', 'heute', 'gestern' ändern sich zu 'dann', 'an diesem Tag', 'am Tag zuvor', weil der Sprecher aus einem anderen Zeitpunkt berichtet.

title: Time references in conditional clauses

titleTranslations.ja: 条件節における時間への言及

rule: Use time expressions like 'when I was younger', 'five years ago', 'now', 'today', 'next year' combined with appropriate conditional forms to show exact time relationships.
explanation: Conditional sentences can reference different time periods by using specific time expressions and appropriate verb forms. This allows us to be precise about when conditions existed and when results occur or occurred.

explanations.ja: 条件文は特定の時間表現と適切な動詞形を使用することで、異なる時間帯を参照することができます。これにより、条件がいつ存在し、結果がいつ起こるか、または起こったかを正確に表現できます。
explanations.de: Konditionalsätze können sich auf verschiedene Zeiträume beziehen, indem sie spezifische Zeitausdrücke und angemessene Verbformen verwenden. Dies ermöglicht es uns, präzise zu sein, wann Bedingungen existierten und wann Ergebnisse auftreten oder aufgetreten sind.

title: basic reported speech structure

titleTranslations.ja: 基本的な間接話法の構造

rule: Subject + said/told + (person) + (that) + reported clause (with tense change)
explanation: When reporting what someone said in the past, the verb tense often changes: present becomes past, past becomes past perfect. The reporting verb (said/told) is in past tense, and the reported clause usually moves one step back in time.

explanations.ja: 過去に誰かが言ったことを報告する際、動詞の時制はしばしば変化します：現在形は過去形に、過去形は過去完了形になります。報告動詞（said/told）は過去形で、報告される節は通常時制が一段階過去にずれます。
explanations.de: Bei der Wiedergabe dessen, was jemand in der Vergangenheit gesagt hat, ändert sich oft die Zeitform: Präsens wird zu Präteritum, Präteritum wird zu Plusquamperfekt. title: choosing passive vs active voice

titleTranslations.ja: 受動態と能動態の選択

rule: Active: Subject + Verb + Object → Passive: Object becomes Subject + be + past participle + (by + original subject). Consider context, emphasis needs, formality level, and whether the agent matters when choosing between forms.
explanation: The strategic decision between using active voice (subject performs action) and passive voice (subject receives action) based on what you want to emphasize, the formality level needed, and whether the agent (doer) is known or important. Active voice emphasizes the doer of the action, while passive voice emphasizes the action itself or the receiver of the action. Choose passive when: 1) The doer is unknown or unimportant, 2) You want to emphasize the action or result, 3) Writing formally or scientifically, 4) The doer is obvious from context, 5) You want to be diplomatic or avoid blame.

explanations.ja: 何を強調したいか、必要な正式さのレベル、行為者（実行者）が知られているか重要かに基づいて、能動態（主語が動作を行う）と受動態（主語が動作を受ける）の戦略的な使い分けです。能動態は動作の実行者を強調し、受動態は動作そのものや動作の受け手を強調します。次の場合に受動態を選択します：1）実行者が不明または重要でない、2）動作や結果を強調したい、3）正式または科学的に書く、4）実行者が文脈から明らか、5）外交的になりたいまたは非難を避けたい。
explanations.de: Die strategische Entscheidung zwischen Aktiv (Subjekt führt Handlung aus) und Passiv (Subjekt empfängt Handlung) basierend darauf, was Sie betonen möchten, dem benötigten Formalitätsgrad und ob der Handelnde bekannt oder wichtig ist. Aktiv betont den Handelnden, Passiv betont die Handlung selbst oder den Empfänger. title: combining clauses effectively

titleTranslations.ja: 効果的な節の結合

rule: Use commas with non-defining relative clauses, semicolons before formal connectors (however, therefore, furthermore), and appropriate subordinating conjunctions (because, although, since, while) without comma when the dependent clause follows the independent clause
explanation: Effective clause combination involves choosing the right connecting words and punctuation to show precise relationships between ideas. This includes using relative clauses for additional information, subordinating conjunctions for cause-effect relationships, and sentence connectors for logical flow between related but independent thoughts.

explanations.ja: 効果的な節の結合には、アイデア間の正確な関係を示すために適切な接続語と句読点を選択することが含まれます。これには追加情報のための関係節、因果関係のための従属接続詞、関連するが独立した思考間の論理的な流れのための文の接続詞の使用が含まれます。
explanations.de: Effektive Satzverbindung beinhaltet die Wahl der richtigen Verbindungswörter und Interpunktion, um präzise Beziehungen zwischen Ideen zu zeigen. Dies schließt Relativsätze für zusätzliche Informationen, unterordnende Konjunktionen für Ursache-Wirkungs-Beziehungen und Satzverbinder für logischen Fluss zwischen verwandten aber unabhängigen Gedanken ein.

title: combining conditional structures

titleTranslations.ja: 条件構造の組み合わせ

rule: Sequential use of different conditionals: First conditional (real) → Second conditional (hypothetical) → Third conditional (past) / Mixed conditionals for different time references / Hypothetical expressions (suppose, unless, provided) combined with conditionals
explanation: Using multiple conditional patterns in sequence or combination to express complex hypothetical scenarios. This includes transitioning between different conditional types within the same conversation or text to show different aspects of a situation - real possibilities, unlikely scenarios, and past regrets.

explanations.ja: 複雑な仮定的シナリオを表現するために、複数の条件パターンを連続または組み合わせで使用することです。これには同じ会話やテキスト内で異なる条件タイプ間を移行して、状況の異なる側面（現実的可能性、起こりにくいシナリオ、過去の後悔）を示すことが含まれます。
explanations.de: Verwendung mehrerer Konditionalmuster in Reihenfolge oder Kombination, um komplexe hypothetische Szenarien auszudrücken. Dies schließt Übergänge zwischen verschiedenen Konditionaltypen innerhalb desselben Gesprächs oder Textes ein, um verschiedene Aspekte einer Situation zu zeigen - reale Möglichkeiten, unwahrscheinliche Szenarien und vergangene Bedauern.

title: combining narrative tenses

titleTranslations.ja: 叙述時制の組み合わせ

rule: Past perfect (had + past participle) for earliest events + past continuous (was/were + -ing) for background + past simple for main story events
explanation: Using past simple, past continuous, and past perfect together to tell complete stories. Past perfect shows what happened first (had + past participle), past continuous shows background actions (was/were + -ing), and past simple shows main events. This creates a clear timeline in narratives.

explanations.ja: 過去形、過去進行形、過去完了形を一緒に使用して完全な物語を語ることです。過去完了は最初に起こったこと（had + 過去分詞）、過去進行形は背景の動作（was/were + -ing）、過去形は主な出来事を示します。これは物語において明確な時間軸を作り出します。
explanations.de: Verwendung von Präteritum, Verlaufsform der Vergangenheit und Plusquamperfekt zusammen, um vollständige Geschichten zu erzählen. Plusquamperfekt zeigt, was zuerst passierte (hatte + Partizip Perfekt), Verlaufsform der Vergangenheit zeigt Hintergrundhandlungen (war/waren + -ing), und Präteritum zeigt Hauptereignisse. Dies schafft eine klare Zeitlinie in Erzählungen.

title: comma usage with extra information

titleTranslations.ja: 追加情報でのカンマの使用

rule: Main clause + comma + extra information + comma + continuation (if any). The extra information can be phrases, clauses, or even single words that provide additional context.
explanation: Commas are essential when adding extra, non-essential information to sentences. This information provides interesting details but could be removed without changing the core meaning of the sentence. The commas act like parentheses, setting off the additional information clearly.

explanations.ja: カンマは文に追加の、必須でない情報を加える際に不可欠です。この情報は興味深い詳細を提供しますが、文の核心的な意味を変えることなく削除できます。カンマは括弧のように機能し、追加情報を明確に区切ります。

title: complex sentence structure

titleTranslations.ja: 複文構造

rule: Independent clause + dependent clause(s) using: subordinating conjunctions (because, although, while, since), relative pronouns (who, which, that), or sentence connectors (however, furthermore, therefore) with proper punctuation
explanation: Complex sentences contain an independent clause (complete thought) combined with one or more dependent clauses (incomplete thoughts that depend on the main clause). They use subordinating conjunctions, relative pronouns, or other connecting words to link ideas in a sophisticated way that shows clear relationships between concepts.

explanations.ja: 複文は独立節（完全な思考）と一つ以上の従属節（主節に依存する不完全な思考）を組み合わせたものです。従属接続詞、関係代名詞、その他の接続語を使用して、概念間の明確な関係を示す洗練された方法でアイデアを結び付けます。
explanations.de: Komplexe Sätze enthalten einen Hauptsatz (vollständiger Gedanke) kombiniert mit einem oder mehreren Nebensätzen (unvollständige Gedanken, die vom Hauptsatz abhängen). Sie verwenden unterordnende Konjunktionen, Relativpronomen oder andere Verbindungswörter, um Ideen auf eine ausgeklügelte Weise zu verknüpfen, die klare Beziehungen zwischen Konzepten zeigt.

title: defining relative clauses with who/which/that

titleTranslations.ja: who/which/thatを使った限定的関係節

rule: Main clause + relative pronoun (who/which/that) + verb + (object/complement). The relative pronoun acts as the subject or object of the relative clause. Example: 'The engineer who designed this bridge' or 'The laptop that I bought yesterday'.
explanation: Relative clauses provide essential information about a noun, defining or identifying which person, thing, or idea we're talking about. 'Who' is used for people, 'which' for things and animals, and 'that' can be used for both people and things in informal contexts. These clauses cannot be removed without changing the meaning of the sentence.

title: first conditional (if + present, will + base verb)

titleTranslations.ja: 第一条件文（if + 現在形、will + 動詞の原形）

rule: If + subject + present simple, subject + will + base verb. OR Subject + will + base verb + if + subject + present simple. Note: 'will' is not used in the 'if' clause.
explanation: The first conditional expresses real possibilities and likely future results based on present or future conditions. It shows cause-and-effect relationships where the condition is realistic and the result is probable. Use this structure when the 'if' situation is possible and you want to talk about the likely consequence. The condition clause uses present simple, while the result clause uses 'will' + base verb. This differs from past narratives because it focuses on future possibilities rather than completed past events.

explanations.ja: 第一条件文は現在または未来の条件に基づく現実的な可能性と可能性の高い未来の結果を表現します。条件が現実的で結果が起こりやすい因果関係を示します。「if」の状況が可能で、その可能性の高い結果について話したいときにこの構造を使用します。条件節は現在単純形を使い、結果節は「will」+ 動詞の原形を使います。これは完了した過去の出来事ではなく未来の可能性に焦点を当てるため、過去の叙述とは異なります。
explanations.de: Die erste Konditionalsform drückt reale Möglichkeiten und wahrscheinliche zukünftige Ergebnisse basierend auf gegenwärtigen oder zukünftigen Bedingungen aus. Sie zeigt Ursache-Wirkungs-Beziehungen, wo die Bedingung realistisch und das Ergebnis wahrscheinlich ist. Verwenden Sie diese Struktur, wenn die 'wenn'-Situation möglich ist und Sie über die wahrscheinliche Konsequenz sprechen möchten. Der Bedingungssatz verwendet Präsens, während der Ergebnissatz 'werden' + Grundverb verwendet. Dies unterscheidet sich von vergangenen Erzählungen, weil es sich auf zukünftige Möglichkeiten anstatt auf abgeschlossene vergangene Ereignisse konzentriert.

rule: Mix of: If + present simple, will + verb (first) / If + past simple, would + verb (second) / If + past perfect, would have + past participle (third) / Mixed forms depending on time reference

title: non-defining relative clauses

titleTranslations.ja: 非限定的関係詞節

rule: Subject + comma + who/which/whose + extra information + comma + rest of sentence. Use 'who' for people, 'which' for things/animals, and 'whose' for possession. The information between commas is optional but interesting.
explanation: Non-defining relative clauses provide additional information about a person, place, or thing that is already clearly identified. Unlike defining relative clauses, this extra information could be removed and the sentence would still make complete sense. They are always separated by commas and cannot use 'that' as the relative pronoun.

explanations.ja: 非限定的関係詞節は、既に明確に特定されている人、場所、物について追加情報を提供します。限定的関係詞節とは異なり、この追加情報は削除しても文は完全に意味をなします。常にコンマで区切られ、関係代名詞として「that」を使用することはできません。
explanations.de: Nicht-bestimmende Relativsätze liefern zusätzliche Informationen über eine Person, einen Ort oder eine Sache, die bereits eindeutig identifiziert ist. Im Gegensatz zu bestimmenden Relativsätzen könnte diese zusätzliche Information entfernt werden und der Satz würde immer noch vollständig Sinn ergeben. Sie werden immer durch Kommas abgetrennt und können nicht 'that' als Relativpronomen verwenden.

rule: Statement about one side + on the other hand + contrasting statement
explanation: Used to introduce a contrasting point or alternative perspective. This linking phrase shows that you are presenting the opposite side of an argument or a different viewpoint. It's essential for balanced discussions and comparing different opinions.

explanation: The passive voice is extensively used in formal, business, and official contexts to describe processes and procedures in an objective, impersonal way. It focuses on the action or result rather than who performs the action, making communication more professional and authoritative. title: passive voice past simple

titleTranslations.ja: 受動態の過去形（単純過去）

rule: Subject + was/were + past participle (+ by + agent). Use 'was' with singular subjects (I, he, she, it) and 'were' with plural subjects (you, we, they). Examples: 'The factory was built in 1995.' 'New machines were installed last month.'
explanation: Past simple passive voice is used to describe actions that happened in the past, focusing on what was done rather than who did it. We use 'was/were + past participle' to show completed actions in the past. This form is commonly used in reports, historical accounts, and when describing past events where the focus is on the action or result.

explanations.ja: 過去形の受動態は過去に起こった行動を描写するときに使われ、誰がそれを行ったかではなく何が行われたかに焦点を当てます。完了した過去の行動を示すために「was/were + 過去分詞」を使います。この形式は報告書、歴史的記述、行動や結果に焦点を当てた過去の出来事を描写するときによく使われます。
explanations.de: Simple Past Passiv wird verwendet, um Handlungen zu beschreiben, die in der Vergangenheit geschehen sind, wobei der Fokus auf dem liegt, was getan wurde, anstatt wer es getan hat. Wir verwenden 'was/were + Past Participle', um abgeschlossene Handlungen in der Vergangenheit zu zeigen. Diese Form wird häufig in Berichten, historischen Darstellungen und bei der Beschreibung vergangener Ereignisse verwendet, bei denen der Fokus auf der Handlung oder dem Ergebnis liegt.

title: passive voice present simple

titleTranslations.ja: 受動態の現在形（単純現在）

rule: Subject + am/is/are + past participle (+ by + agent). Examples: 'Cars are manufactured in this factory.' 'The equipment is tested every day.' Use 'by + agent' only when the doer is important or relevant.
explanation: The passive voice is used when we want to focus on the action or the person/thing receiving the action, rather than who performs the action. In present simple passive, we use 'am/is/are + past participle' to show that something happens regularly or is a general fact. This is especially common when describing processes, manufacturing, or when the person doing the action is unknown or unimportant.

explanations.ja: 受動態は、誰が行動を実行するかではなく、行動や行動を受ける人・物に焦点を当てたいときに使われます。現在形の受動態では、定期的に起こることや一般的な事実を示すために「am/is/are + 過去分詞」を使います。これは特にプロセス、製造業、または行動を行う人が不明または重要でないときの説明でよく見られます。

title: past continuous for background actions

titleTranslations.ja: 背景動作のための過去進行形

rule: Subject + was/were + verb + -ing. Use 'was' with I, he, she, it; use 'were' with you, we, they. Example: 'I was working when the phone rang.'
explanation: The past continuous (was/were + -ing) describes ongoing actions that were happening at a specific time in the past or that provided background context for other events. It sets the scene and shows what was in progress when something else happened. This pattern is essential for storytelling as it helps establish the setting and atmosphere.

explanations.ja: 過去進行形（was/were + -ing）は、過去の特定の時間に進行していた継続的な行動や、他の出来事の背景文脈を提供していた行動を描写します。場面を設定し、他の何かが起こったときに進行中だったことを示します。このパターンは物語において場面や雰囲気を確立するのに役立つため、ストーリーテリングに不可欠です。
explanations.de: Das Past Continuous (was/were + -ing) beschreibt andauernde Handlungen, die zu einem bestimmten Zeitpunkt in der Vergangenheit geschahen oder die Hintergrundkontext für andere Ereignisse lieferten. Es setzt die Szene und zeigt, was gerade ablief, als etwas anderes passierte. Dieses Muster ist wesentlich für das Erzählen, da es hilft, die Szenerie und Atmosphäre zu etablieren.

title: past continuous vs past simple

titleTranslations.ja: 過去進行形 vs 過去形

rule: Past continuous: was/were + verb-ing. Past simple: verb + -ed (regular) or irregular past form. Often combined: 'I was cooking when the phone rang.'
explanation: Past continuous (was/were + -ing) describes ongoing background actions, while past simple describes completed actions that interrupted or happened during the background action. Use past continuous for longer actions in progress and past simple for shorter, completed actions.

explanations.ja: 過去進行形（was/were + -ing）は進行中の背景動作を描写し、過去形は背景動作を中断したり、その最中に起こった完了した行動を描写します。進行中の長い行動には過去進行形を、短い完了した行動には過去形を使います。
explanations.de: Past Continuous (was/were + -ing) beschreibt andauernde Hintergrundhandlungen, während Simple Past abgeschlossene Handlungen beschreibt, die die Hintergrundhandlung unterbrachen oder während dieser geschahen. Verwenden Sie Past Continuous für längere, andauernde Handlungen und Simple Past für kürzere, abgeschlossene Handlungen.

title: past perfect (had + past participle)

titleTranslations.ja: 過去完了形（had + 過去分詞）

rule: Subject + had + past participle. Examples: I had eaten, She had arrived, They had finished. Negative: Subject + had not (hadn't) + past participle. Question: Had + subject + past participle?
explanation: Used to show that one action happened before another action in the past. It creates a clear sequence of events and shows which action was completed first. The past perfect is always used in relation to another past time or action.

explanations.ja: 過去のある行動が別の過去の行動よりも前に起こったことを示すために使われます。明確な出来事の順序を作り、どの行動が最初に完了したかを示します。過去完了は常に他の過去の時間や行動との関連で使われます。
explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um zu zeigen, dass eine Handlung vor einer anderen Handlung in der Vergangenheit geschah. Es schafft eine klare Abfolge von Ereignissen und zeigt, welche Handlung zuerst abgeschlossen war. Das Plusquamperfekt wird immer in Bezug auf eine andere vergangene Zeit oder Handlung verwendet.

title: past perfect vs past simple

titleTranslations.ja: 過去完了形 vs 過去形

rule: Earlier action: had + past participle. Later action: past simple. Example: 'After I had eaten (earlier), I watched TV (later).' Can also be: 'I watched TV after I had eaten.'
explanation: Past perfect shows which action happened first, past simple shows what happened next. Use past perfect for the earlier action and past simple for the later action. This creates clear chronological sequence in storytelling.

explanations.ja: 過去完了はどの行動が最初に起こったかを示し、過去形は次に起こったことを示します。先の行動には過去完了を、後の行動には過去形を使います。これによってストーリーテリングで明確な時系列順序を作ります。

title: say vs tell - basic distinction

titleTranslations.ja: say vs tell - 基本的な区別

rule: say + (that) + reported statement OR tell + person + (that) + reported statement
explanation: Two main reporting verbs with different usage: 'say' is used to report words directly, while 'tell' requires a person object and focuses on communication to someone specific. Say focuses on the words spoken, tell focuses on the communication to a person.

explanations.ja: 二つの主要な報告動詞で使い方が異なります：'say'は言葉を直接報告するのに使い、'tell'は人を目的語として必要とし、特定の誰かへの伝達に焦点を当てます。Sayは話された言葉に、tellは人への伝達に焦点を当てます。
explanations.de: Zwei wichtige Verben des Berichtens mit unterschiedlicher Verwendung: 'say' wird verwendet, um Worte direkt zu berichten, während 'tell' ein Personenobjekt erfordert und sich auf die Kommunikation an jemand Bestimmtes konzentriert. Say konzentriert sich auf die gesprochenen Worte, tell konzentriert sich auf die Kommunikation an eine Person.

title: second conditional (if + past simple, would + base verb)

titleTranslations.ja: 仮定法過去（if + 過去形、would + 動詞の原形）
titleTranslations.de: zweiter Konditional (if + past simple, would + Grundverb)

rule: If + subject + past simple verb, subject + would + base verb (infinitive without 'to'). Example: If I had time, I would travel more. Note: Use 'were' for all persons with the verb 'be' (If I were rich, If he were here).
explanation: Used to talk about imaginary, hypothetical, or unreal situations in the present or future. It describes what would happen if a condition (that is probably not true) were met. explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um über imaginäre, hypothetische oder unwirkliche Situationen in der Gegenwart oder Zukunft zu sprechen. Er beschreibt, was passieren würde, wenn eine Bedingung (die wahrscheinlich nicht wahr ist) erfüllt wäre. Dieser Konditional drückt Träume, Wünsche, Ratschläge und Spekulationen über Situationen aus, die sich von der Realität unterscheiden.

title: sentence connectors with punctuation

titleTranslations.ja: 文章連結語の句読点

rule: Pattern 1: Independent clause; connector, independent clause. Pattern 2: Independent clause. Connector, independent clause. Examples: 'The weather was bad; however, we enjoyed our trip.' OR 'The weather was bad. However, we enjoyed our trip.'
explanation: Formal connectors that link sentences or clauses to show relationships between ideas. These include contrast (however, nevertheless), addition (furthermore, moreover), and result (therefore, consequently). They require specific punctuation: semicolon before + comma after when connecting independent clauses, or period before + comma after when starting new sentences.

explanations.ja: 文や節を結んでアイデア間の関係を示すフォーマルな連結語。これには対比（however、nevertheless）、付加（furthermore、moreover）、結果（therefore、consequently）が含まれます。特定の句読点が必要です：独立節を結ぶときはセミコロンの後にコンマ、または新しい文を始めるときはピリオドの後にコンマ。
explanations.de: Formelle Verbindungswörter, die Sätze oder Satzteile verknüpfen, um Beziehungen zwischen Ideen zu zeigen. Diese umfassen Kontrast (however, nevertheless), Ergänzung (furthermore, moreover) und Ergebnis (therefore, consequently). Sie erfordern spezielle Zeichensetzung: Semikolon davor + Komma danach beim Verbinden unabhängiger Satzteile, oder Punkt davor + Komma danach beim Beginnen neuer Sätze.

explanation: Words that connect a dependent clause to an independent clause, showing relationships like cause (because, since), contrast (although, while), or time (while, since). The dependent clause cannot stand alone.

explanations.ja: 従属節を独立節に接続し、原因（because、since）、対比（although、while）、時間（while、since）などの関係を示す語。従属節は単独では成り立ちません。
explanations.de: Wörter, die einen abhängigen Nebensatz mit einem unabhängigen Hauptsatz verbinden und Beziehungen wie Ursache (because, since), Kontrast (although, while) oder Zeit (while, since) zeigen. Der abhängige Nebensatz kann nicht allein stehen.

title: text cohesion devices

titleTranslations.ja: テキストの結束装置

rule: Use reference pronouns (it, this, these, they), repeat key words, use synonyms, and employ transition words to link sentences and paragraphs
explanation: Text cohesion refers to how well the parts of a text connect together. Cohesion devices include reference words (this, that, it), repetition of key terms, synonyms, and connecting words. These create clear links between sentences and help readers follow ideas smoothly.

explanations.ja: テキストの結束とは、テキストの各部分がどれだけうまく結びついているかを指します。結束装置には指示語（this、that、it）、キーワードの繰り返し、同義語、接続語が含まれます。これらは文間の明確なつながりを作り、読者がアイデアをスムーズに追えるようにします。
explanations.de: Textkohäsion bezieht sich darauf, wie gut die Teile eines Textes zusammenhängen. Kohäsionsmittel umfassen Bezugswörter (this, that, it), Wiederholung von Schlüsselbegriffen, Synonyme und Verbindungswörter. Diese schaffen klare Verbindungen zwischen Sätzen und helfen Lesern, Ideen reibungslos zu verfolgen.

title: time linkers in narratives

titleTranslations.ja: 物語における時間連結語

rule: Time linker + clause OR clause + time linker + clause. Position varies: 'Meanwhile, she was cooking' or 'She was cooking meanwhile'
explanation: Words and phrases that connect events in time order within stories: meanwhile, afterwards, by the time, as soon as, until, since then. These help readers follow the sequence of events and understand relationships between different parts of the story.

explanations.ja: 物語内で出来事を時間順に結ぶ語句：meanwhile、afterwards、by the time、as soon as、until、since then。これらは読者が出来事の順序を追い、物語の異なる部分間の関係を理解するのに役立ちます。
explanations.de: Wörter und Phrasen, die Ereignisse in zeitlicher Reihenfolge innerhalb von Geschichten verbinden: meanwhile, afterwards, by the time, as soon as, until, since then. title: to sum up / in conclusion

titleTranslations.ja: 要するに / 結論として

rule: 'To sum up' + main point(s) / 'In conclusion' + final statement or summary
explanation: These phrases signal the end of an argument or discussion and introduce a summary of the main points. They help organize thoughts and provide closure to formal and informal debates.

title: while/when clauses

titleTranslations.ja: while/when節

rule: While + past continuous, past simple OR Past simple + while + past continuous. When + past simple, past continuous OR Past continuous + when + past simple.
explanation: While introduces longer background actions (usually past continuous). When introduces shorter, completed actions (usually past simple) that interrupt or happen during the background action. These clauses help sequence events in narratives.

explanations.ja: Whileは長い背景的な動作（通常過去進行形）を導入します。Whenは短い、完了した動作（通常過去形）を導入し、背景的動作を中断したり、その間に起こったりします。これらの節は物語での出来事の順序を整理するのに役立ちます。
explanations.de: While führt längere Hintergrundhandlungen ein (normalerweise past continuous). When führt kürzere, abgeschlossene Handlungen ein (normalerweise past simple), die die Hintergrundhandlung unterbrechen oder währenddessen geschehen. Diese Nebensätze helfen dabei, Ereignisse in Erzählungen zu ordnen.

title: Although/While/Whereas + concession, main argument

titleTranslations.ja: Although/While/Whereas + 譲歩、主要論証

rule: Concession connector + subject + verb + conceded point, subject + verb + main argument. Common connectors: Although, While, Whereas, Even though, Despite the fact that
explanation: Complex conditional structures that acknowledge opposing viewpoints while maintaining your position. These patterns create sophisticated argumentation by showing intellectual fairness before presenting counter-evidence. The concession clause admits some validity to the opposing view, while the main clause asserts your stronger position.

explanations.de: Komplexe Konditionalsätze, die gegensätzliche Standpunkte anerkennen, während sie Ihre Position beibehalten. Diese Muster schaffen ausgeklügelte Argumentation, indem sie intellektuelle Fairness zeigen, bevor sie Gegenbeweise präsentieren. Der Zugeständnissatz gibt der gegensätzlichen Ansicht etwas Gültigkeit zu, während der Hauptsatz Ihre stärkere Position behauptet.

title: By the time + Future Perfect Continuous

titleTranslations.ja: By the time + 未来完了進行形
titleTranslations.de: By the time + Future Perfect Continuous

rule: By the time + (simple present clause), + subject + will have been + verb-ing + duration
explanation: This construction connects a future time marker with the duration of an ongoing action up to that point. 'By the time' introduces a future moment, while the future perfect continuous shows how long something will have been happening up to that moment.

explanations.ja: この構造は未来の時間マーカーをその時点までの継続的な動作の期間と結びつけます。'By the time'は未来のある瞬間を導入し、未来完了進行形はその瞬間までに何かがどのくらい長く続いているかを示します。
explanations.de: Diese Konstruktion verbindet einen zukünftigen Zeitmarker mit der Dauer einer andauernden Handlung bis zu diesem Punkt. 'By the time' führt einen zukünftigen Moment ein, während das Future Perfect Continuous zeigt, wie lange etwas bis zu diesem Moment andauern wird.

patterns: By the time + Future Perfect Continuous

title: Cleft sentences for emphasis (It is/was + focus + that/who/which)

titleTranslations.ja: 強調の分裂文（It is/was + 焦点 + that/who/which）

rule: It + is/was + emphasized element + that/who/which + rest of sentence. Example: 'It was the evidence that convinced me' (emphasizing 'evidence')
explanation: Cleft sentences are used to emphasize specific parts of a sentence by restructuring it. They highlight important information by placing it in a prominent position, making the emphasis clear to the listener or reader.

explanations.ja: 分裂文は文の特定の部分を強調するために文を再構成して使用されます。重要な情報を目立つ位置に置くことで強調を聞き手や読み手にとって明確にします。

title: Completed vs Ongoing Emphasis

titleTranslations.ja: 完了と継続の強調

rule: For completed emphasis: have/has + past participle (focuses on result). For ongoing emphasis: have/has been + verb-ing (focuses on process or duration). The same situation can often be described both ways depending on what aspect you want to highlight.
explanation: When choosing between present perfect and present perfect continuous, consider whether you want to emphasize completion/achievement (perfect) or ongoing process/duration (continuous). This choice affects the focus and meaning of your communication, highlighting either results or activities.

explanations.ja: 現在完了と現在完了進行形を選ぶときは、完了・達成を強調したいか（完了）、継続的なプロセス・期間を強調したいか（進行）を考慮してください。この選択は伝達の焦点と意味に影響し、結果または活動のどちらを強調するかが変わります。
explanations.de: Bei der Wahl zwischen Present Perfect und Present Perfect Continuous sollten Sie überlegen, ob Sie Vollendung/Leistung (Perfect) oder andauernden Prozess/Dauer (Continuous) betonen möchten. Diese Wahl beeinflusst den Fokus und die Bedeutung Ihrer Kommunikation und hebt entweder Ergebnisse oder Aktivitäten hervor.

title: Complex causal constructions

titleTranslations.ja: 複雑な因果構造

rule: Given that + clause / In light of + noun phrase / Owing to the fact that + clause / By virtue of + noun phrase / On account of + noun phrase / In view of + noun phrase + main clause
explanation: Advanced ways to express cause-and-effect relationships using sophisticated linking language including 'given that', 'in light of', 'owing to the fact that', 'by virtue of', 'on account of', and 'in view of'. title: Conditional politeness (If you could... / If it would be possible...)

titleTranslations.ja: 条件的丁寧語（If you could... / If it would be possible...）

title: Conditionals for Persuasion

titleTranslations.ja: 説得のための条件文

rule: If + condition, + persuasive consequence (If we act now, we will see immediate benefits.) / Unless + condition, + negative outcome (Unless we change our approach, we will face serious problems.) / Provided that + condition, + positive assurance (Provided that we follow this plan, success is guaranteed.)
explanation: Using conditional structures strategically in arguments to present consequences, benefits, or potential outcomes to persuade others. This includes emphasizing positive outcomes with first conditionals, warning of negative consequences, and creating urgency through time-sensitive conditions.

explanations.ja: 他者を説得するために論証で条件構造を戦略的に使用し、結果、利益、または潜在的成果を提示すること。これには第一条件文で肯定的成果を強調し、否定的結果を警告し、時間制約のある条件を通して緊急性を作り出すことが含まれる。
explanations.de: Die strategische Verwendung konditionaler Strukturen in Argumenten, um Konsequenzen, Vorteile oder potenzielle Ergebnisse zu präsentieren, um andere zu überzeugen. title: Cross-reference pronouns (this, that, these, those + noun)

titleTranslations.ja: 相互参照代名詞（this, that, these, those + 名詞）

rule: this/that + singular noun, these/those + plural noun. The noun should clearly identify what is being referenced (e.g., 'this argument', 'these findings', 'that approach', 'those concerns').
explanation: Demonstrative determiners used with nouns to refer back to specific ideas, concepts, or entire arguments from previous paragraphs. 'This/these' typically refer to more recent or closer ideas, while 'that/those' refer to more distant or earlier mentioned concepts. Essential for creating cohesive links across paragraph boundaries without repetition.

explanations.ja: 前の段落からの特定の考え、概念、または議論全体を参照するために名詞と一緒に使用される指示限定詞。「This/these」は通常より最近のまたはより近い考えを指し、「that/those」はより遠いまたは以前に言及された概念を指す。反復なしに段落境界を越えて結束的つながりを作成するために不可欠。
explanations.de: Demonstrativbestimmer, die mit Nomen verwendet werden, um auf spezifische Ideen, Konzepte oder ganze Argumente aus vorherigen Absätzen zu verweisen. 'This/these' beziehen sich typischerweise auf neuere oder näherliegende Ideen, während 'that/those' sich auf entferntere oder früher erwähnte Konzepte beziehen. Wesentlich für die Schaffung kohäsiver Verbindungen über Absatzgrenzen hinweg ohne Wiederholung.

title: Demonstrative cohesion (such + noun, the former/latter)

titleTranslations.ja: 指示的結束（such + 名詞, the former/latter）

rule: 'Such + noun' where the noun categorizes the referenced concept. 'The former/latter' when exactly two items have been mentioned in previous text.
explanation: Advanced cohesive devices that create precise references to previously mentioned concepts. 'Such + noun' refers to the type or category of something mentioned before. 'The former' refers to the first of two items mentioned, while 'the latter' refers to the second. These create sophisticated paragraph-to-paragraph connections in academic writing.

explanations.ja: 以前に言及された概念への正確な参照を作成する高度な結束装置。「Such + 名詞」は以前に言及された物事の種類やカテゴリーを指す。「The former」は言及された二つの項目の最初を指し、「the latter」は二番目を指す。これらは学術的文章で洗練された段落間のつながりを作成する。
explanations.de: Fortgeschrittene kohäsive Mittel, die präzise Verweise auf zuvor erwähnte Konzepte schaffen. 'Such + Nomen' bezieht sich auf den Typ oder die Kategorie von etwas, das zuvor erwähnt wurde. 'The former' bezieht sich auf das erste von zwei erwähnten Elementen, während 'the latter' sich auf das zweite bezieht. Diese schaffen ausgeklügelte Absatz-zu-Absatz-Verbindungen in akademischem Schreiben.

title: Future Perfect Continuous Formation

titleTranslations.ja: 未来完了進行形の形成

rule: Subject + will + have + been + verb-ing + (for/since + time expression)
explanation: The future perfect continuous tense describes actions that will be ongoing for a period of time before a specific point in the future. It emphasizes the duration of the action up to that future moment. This tense projects how long something will have been happening by a certain time.

explanations.ja: 未来完了進行時制は、未来の特定の時点より前にある期間継続する行動を説明する。その未来の瞬間までの行動の継続時間を強調する。この時制は特定の時期までに何かがどのくらいの期間起こっているかを投影する。
explanations.de: Das Futur II Kontinuierlich beschreibt Handlungen, die über einen Zeitraum andauern werden, bevor ein bestimmter Punkt in der Zukunft erreicht wird. Es betont die Dauer der Handlung bis zu diesem zukünftigen Moment. Diese Zeitform projiziert, wie lange etwas bis zu einem bestimmten Zeitpunkt geschehen sein wird.

titleTranslations.ja: Granted/Admittedly/True + 譲歩 + but/however/nonetheless + 反駁

rule: Concession marker + acknowledgment statement + contrast connector + rebuttal statement. Concession markers: Granted, Admittedly, True, It is true that, I accept that. Contrast connectors: but, however, nonetheless, nevertheless, yet
explanation: Sophisticated contrast and concession markers that structure formal counter-arguments. These discourse markers signal intellectual maturity by acknowledging opposing strengths before presenting stronger counter-evidence. They create a respectful but firm argumentative tone essential for academic and professional contexts.

title: Impersonal constructions

titleTranslations.ja: 非人称構文

rule: 1) It is + adjective + that clause: 'It is evident that...'; 2) It + passive + that: 'It has been established that...'; 3) There + passive: 'There is observed...'; 4) Abstract subjects: 'The evidence suggests...', 'Research indicates...'
explanation: Formal structures that remove personal agency and create objective, academic tone. These include: 'It is + adjective + that/to', passive voice constructions, and abstract subject constructions. They make arguments appear more authoritative and less subjective.

title: Integrated Perfect Continuous Narrative Sequences

rule: Combine different perfect continuous aspects within connected sentences or paragraphs: Past Perfect Continuous (had been + verb-ing) for background actions, Present Perfect Continuous (have/has been + verb-ing) for ongoing relevance, and Future Perfect Continuous (will have been + verb-ing) for projected duration, connected with narrative transition words and temporal markers.
explanation: The sophisticated combination of present perfect continuous, past perfect continuous, and future perfect continuous tenses to create complex, multi-layered narratives that show relationships between different time periods and ongoing actions. explanations.de: Die ausgeklügelte Kombination von Präsens Perfekt Kontinuierlich, Plusquamperfekt Kontinuierlich und Futur II Kontinuierlich, um komplexe, vielschichtige Erzählungen zu schaffen, die Beziehungen zwischen verschiedenen Zeiträumen und andauernden Handlungen zeigen. title: It + be + focused element + that/who + clause

titleTranslations.ja: It + be + 強調する要素 + that/who + 節
titleTranslations.de: Es + be + fokussiertes Element + that/who + Nebensatz

rule: It + is/was + [emphasized element] + that/who/which + [rest of clause]. Use 'who' for people, 'that' for things/people (less formal), 'which' for things (formal). The verb tense in the cleft matches the time reference of the original sentence.
explanation: Cleft sentences are used to emphasize a particular part of a sentence by moving it to a prominent position. The structure divides (cleaves) the sentence into two parts: the focused element and the background information. This construction draws strong attention to the emphasized element and is commonly used in formal discourse to highlight key points, contrast information, or correct misconceptions.

explanations.ja: 分裂文は、文の特定の部分を目立つ位置に移動させることで強調するために使われます。この構造は文を2つの部分に分割（分裂）します：強調される要素と背景情報です。この構文は強調される要素に強い注意を向け、重要なポイントを強調したり、情報を対比したり、誤解を訂正したりするために、特にフォーマルな文章でよく使われます。
explanations.de: Spaltsätze werden verwendet, um einen bestimmten Teil eines Satzes zu betonen, indem er in eine hervorstechende Position gerückt wird. Die Struktur teilt (spaltet) den Satz in zwei Teile: das fokussierte Element und die Hintergrundinformation. Diese Konstruktion lenkt starke Aufmerksamkeit auf das betonte Element und wird häufig im formellen Diskurs verwendet, um Schlüsselpunkte hervorzuheben, Informationen zu kontrastieren oder Missverständnisse zu korrigieren.

title: Mixed Conditionals: Past Condition → Present Result

titleTranslations.ja: 混合仮定法：過去の条件→現在の結果

rule: If + past perfect, would + base verb (present result)
explanation: Used to express how a past action or decision affects the present situation. The condition is in the past (using past perfect), but the result is happening now (using would + base verb). This shows how past events continue to influence our current circumstances.

explanations.ja: 過去の行動や決定が現在の状況にどう影響するかを表現するために使われます。条件は過去（過去完了を使用）にありますが、結果は現在起こっています（would + 動詞の原形を使用）。これは過去の出来事が現在の状況に継続して影響していることを示します。
explanations.de: Wird verwendet, um auszudrücken, wie eine vergangene Handlung oder Entscheidung die gegenwärtige Situation beeinflusst. Die Bedingung liegt in der Vergangenheit (mit Past Perfect), aber das Ergebnis geschieht jetzt (mit would + Grundform). Dies zeigt, wie vergangene Ereignisse weiterhin unsere aktuellen Umstände beeinflussen.

title: Negative adverb + auxiliary/modal + subject + main verb

titleTranslations.ja: 否定の副詞 + 助動詞/法助動詞 + 主語 + 本動詞

rule: After negative adverbs (never, rarely, seldom, hardly, barely, not only, nowhere, under no circumstances, on no account), invert the auxiliary verb and subject. If there's no auxiliary, add 'do/does/did'. For modal verbs, invert the modal and subject directly.
explanation: Inversion for emphasis involves reversing the normal word order (subject + verb) to (auxiliary/modal + subject + main verb) after negative adverbs or expressions. This creates dramatic emphasis and is particularly effective in formal writing and speeches. The inversion draws attention to the negative condition and creates a more striking, memorable statement.

explanations.ja: 強調のための倒置は、否定の副詞や表現の後で、通常の語順（主語 + 動詞）を（助動詞/法助動詞 + 主語 + 本動詞）に逆転させることです。これは劇的な強調を作り出し、特にフォーマルな文章や演説で効果的です。倒置は否定的な条件に注意を向け、より印象的で記憶に残る文を作ります。
explanations.de: Inversion zur Betonung beinhaltet die Umkehrung der normalen Wortstellung (Subjekt + Verb) zu (Hilfsverb/Modal + Subjekt + Hauptverb) nach negativen Adverbien oder Ausdrücken. Dies erzeugt dramatische Betonung und ist besonders wirkungsvoll im formellen Schreiben und in Reden. Die Inversion lenkt Aufmerksamkeit auf die negative Bedingung und schafft eine markantere, einprägsame Aussage.

title: Nominalization patterns

titleTranslations.ja: 名詞化のパターン

rule: 1) Verb + suffix: analyze → analysis, investigate → investigation; 2) Adjective + suffix: complex → complexity, important → importance; 3) Gerunds: examining, understanding; 4) Abstract nouns: the fact that → the reality, what happens → the occurrence
explanation: The process of turning verbs and adjectives into nouns for formal academic writing. This creates more sophisticated, impersonal discourse by focusing on concepts rather than actions. Common patterns include: verb + -tion/-sion (analyze → analysis), adjective + -ness/-ity (complex → complexity), and gerund forms (understanding, examining).

explanations.de: Der Prozess der Umwandlung von Verben und Adjektiven in Substantive für formelles akademisches Schreiben. Häufige Muster sind: Verb + -tion/-sion (analyze → analysis), Adjektiv + -ness/-ity (complex → complexity) und Gerundiumformen (understanding, examining).

rule: Subject + had been + verb-ing. For questions: Had + subject + been + verb-ing? For negatives: Subject + had not been + verb-ing.
explanation: The past perfect continuous tense is used to describe actions that were in progress before another past event occurred. explanations.de: Das Past Perfect Continuous wird verwendet, um Handlungen zu beschreiben, die vor einem anderen vergangenen Ereignis im Gange waren.
